title: AB 1847
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The Legislature amended Section 19851 of the Revenue and Taxation Code to address the low participation rate in the federal Earned Income Tax Credit program. In 2015, California authorized a state EITC to help the poorest working Californians. In 2015, California authorized a state EITC to amplify the poverty-reducing effects of the federal EITC for the poorest working Californians. The state aims to alleviate the tax burden on working poor individuals and families, enhance their wages and income, ensure access to both federal and state EITC, and inject additional federal money into the California economy through information dissemination. California has implemented a state EITC to complement the federal EITC for eligible residents. The amendment clarifies terms related to the EITC and outlines state departments and agencies that can assist individuals in claiming both credits. The State Department of Education, Employment Development Department, and State Department of Health Care Services provide assistance programs such as free or reduced-price meals, California Unemployment Insurance, and the Medi-Cal program. Employers are required to notify employees about eligibility for federal and California EITC when providing annual wage summaries. State departments and agencies must inform program recipients annually about potential eligibility for federal and California EITC through various communication methods. Indirect communication is allowed through other entities serving eligible individuals. Effective notification methods should mirror the language specified in Section 19854. The employer must provide notification directly to the employee or by mail, including instructions on obtaining IRS and Franchise Tax Board notices. Posting on a bulletin board or sending through office mail does not fulfill the requirement. Amendments apply to notices given after the effective date. Section 19854 of the Revenue and Taxation Code is amended to specify the language for notices regarding federal and California EITC eligibility. The Federal Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC) is available for low-income working individuals and families based on annual earnings. It does not affect certain welfare benefits like Medicaid, food stamps, or low-income housing. Even if you don't owe federal taxes, you must file a tax return to receive the EITC. Contact the IRS for more information on eligibility and how to obtain necessary forms. The California Earned Income Tax Credit (California EITC) is a refundable state income tax credit for low-income working individuals and families. To claim the California EITC, you must file a California income tax return and complete the California EITC form (FTB 3514). Contact the Franchise Tax Board for more information on eligibility and how to obtain necessary forms. Amendments to this section apply to notices furnished on or after the effective date of the act.
